text:
Anthony Bourdain. Business Insider/Sarah Jacobs

Anthony Bourdain's will has been obtained — and it is said to reveal a net worth far below what previous estimates had him pinned at.

According to court papers acquired by Page Six, Bourdain's assets amount to $1.21 million. The "Parts Unknown" host's net worth had previously been estimated at about $16 million.

The papers filed in Manhattan Surrogate's Court showed that Bourdain had $425,000 in "cash and savings," $35,000 in a brokerage account, $250,000 in "personal property," and $500,000 in "intangible property including royalties and residuals."

The will reportedly says Bourdain's 11-year-old daughter, Ariane Busia-Bourdain, will receive most of his fortune. Ariane's mother, Bourdain's ex-wife Ottavia Busia, is the executor of his estate.

Since his divorce with Busia was never formalized, she is legally still his next of kin. Bourdain reportedly left Busia his air miles, which he asks her in the will to "dispose of in accordance with what [she] believes to have been my wishes."

Bourdain and his ex-wife Ottavia Busia. Evan Agostini/Invision/AP

People reports that the court will appoint a guardian to protect Ariane Busia-Bourdain's interests in her father's estate because she is a minor.

The celebrity chef's New York condo, which was reported to be worth $3.35 million when he bought it in 2014, was not included in the will, but the filings indicate a $1 million mortgage liability for an unspecified property.

"I own an apartment with a mortgage that my ex-wife and my daughter live in, and I'm a renter," Bourdain told People in February. "I should always be a renter. I regret buying that apartment. The bank owns it, and then you're stuck with it."

The will was apparently written in 2016 before his split with Busia. Bourdain was dating the actress and activist Asia Argento at the time of his death by suicide.

Bourdain was in France working on Season 12 of "Parts Unknown" when he was discovered dead in his hotel room.
